label.intro:
A step beyond measuring (or considering) or ignoring a variable in a design is to control variability. The key idea with controlling variability is to use different design aspects to protect the study from biases and misinterpretations. This can help minimise the risk of errors or bias in the results, and also allow for generalisability in the findings of the study.


This is fundamentally where an opportunistic study becomes an experiment or survey.


The layout of a study is a fundamental tool to help control and manage variability in a study design. The approach used in the layout of the study can help optimise the information and hence inferences that come from the design. The basic design principles relating to controlling variability is in replication, randomisation, and stratification.
